lexUnit.name: alert.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: quick to notice and respond

sentence.text: Always be alert for a bad swing or a wing-tip touching the ground on take off and have your hand near the release , ready .
An amorous meeting is forecast , so keep yourself smart , sociable and suitably alert for what promises to be an interesting episode .
We should be alert for the side-effects of critical doubt .
Harbury 's green eyes were alert for her slightest response .

In commercial computer applications , he believes sound will be particularly important in collaborative tasks , where people need to be alert to what colleagues are doing , without having it distractingly thrust upon their attention .
If he had been alert to everyday things he knew he would have heard it sooner .
From the moment you first suspect you 're pregnant , you are alert to each change in your body and the way you feel .
Parents , and GPs must be alert to the symptoms .
He said : ` We would urge people to be aware and be alert with fireworks because your fun might be someone else 's tragedy . "
Much of the game was taken up with mauls which an alert French referee often had to turn into scrums .
Conscious of advancing years , the league always allowed four subs until an alert referee wrote to Durham FA pointing out that international law allowed only two , regardless of age .
It owes its second chance of life to an alert dock worker .
They were both jumpy and alert .
He will be less alert , more pliable .
Kim woke and lay there in the darkness , strangely alert , listening .
She heard his key in the door , and sat alert .
It was going to be another protracted day ; he had to stay alert and miss nothing .
So whatever suggestion is in the subconscious will continue to have effect even if the patient is not sufficiently alert to notice it .
